question.title: Environment Minister
question.notes: Residents and motorists are hopping mad ever since an exploding frog population has overrun local gardens and roadways. Your constituency's evening paper has called it 'The Green Plague'.

questions.text: Can the Minister tell us why she is known as a 'frontbencher'?
questions.feedback: 'I'm the Government's main spokesperson on the environment!' she said.

questions.text: What recent meetings has the Minister had with local councils about the management of wildlife and pests?
questions.feedback: Your constituents were happy you stuck up for them.

questions.text: Has the Minister ever had frog legs?
questions.feedback: Be careful with silly questions. Your constituents read about them in the press.

questions.text: What steps have been taken by the Minister to control dangerous diseases in the animal population?
questions.feedback: That question didn't help your constituents, unless all frogs in the constituency develop a dangerous disease.

missed.feedback: You missed out. Question Time is a good chance to check what the Government has been doing for your constituents and everyone else in the country.

question.title: Business Minister
question.notes: Thousands of British workers are set to lose their jobs after an electronics manufacturer decided to move all its factories overseas. Quell Electronics will close all six of its UK plants putting almost 3,000 people out of jobs.

questions.text: Can the minister tell us what 'democracy' means?
questions.feedback: As an MP you should already know that democracy means Government by the people (or their elected representatives).

questions.text: What plans do the Government have for helping workers of Quell Electronics find other jobs or to retrain?
questions.feedback: Good question. This is a big national issue in the media.

questions.text: Can the Minister give his estimate of how many people are employed in the fast food business sector?
questions.feedback: Are you interested in the fast food business? A good question, but the Minister and your party weren't interested in it.

questions.text: Would the Minister recommend putting his money into stocks or shares?
questions.feedback: Thinking of investing? The Business Minister's job isn't to give out stock tips.

missed.feedback: Question Time is a good opportunity to check the work of the Government and raise your own profile to show that you're working for your constituents.

question.title: Global Affairs Minister
question.notes: The Global Affairs Minister has made a speech reconfirming the Government's commitment to giving money and aid to poor countries. Charlie Curtis MP said: 'Millions of people are alive today because of foreign aid.'

questions.text: I'd like to congratulate the Minister on the Government's foreign aid programme. Will the Government continue to maintain aid levels to help the world's poorest?
questions.feedback: The Minister was happy to get that question!

questions.text: Can the Minister explain why some money given to developing countries ends up being wasted or squandered by corrupt politicians?
questions.feedback: Are you thinking of switching to the Opposition party?

questions.text: Will the Minister join me in celebrating World Turtle Day?
questions.feedback: The Minister wasn't interested in spending much time on your question.

questions.text: Will the Minister make a statement about the Government's aid programme in Africa?
questions.feedback: The Minister's answer listed plenty of Government success stories.

questions.text: It is all well and good giving money and resources to help developing countries, but what's in it for the UK?
questions.feedback: You might have a point, but most didn't like the tone of your question.

missed.feedback: You missed out. Question Time is a good chance to check what the Government has been doing for your constituents and everyone else in the country.

question.title: Prime Minister
question.notes: MPs fill the House of Commons Chamber to be part of Prime Minister's Questions. This is when MPs have the chance to ask the Prime Minister about anything the Government is doing.

questions.text: Can the Prime Minister make a statement about the effectiveness of foreign aid to the developing world?
questions.feedback: A good question for the party. The Prime Minister was able to talk about the Government's successes.

questions.text: A high profile robbery has been carried out by a thief released early from jail. Will the Prime Minister admit the Government's approach to prison sentencing has failed?
questions.feedback: Your question criticised the Prime Minister and the governing party's policy.

questions.text: Does the Prime Minister know what the capital of Indonesia is?
questions.feedback: It's Jakarta. Your questioning style was treated harshly by the papers: 'Clueless MP embarrasses party'.

questions.text: One of my constituents recently won a prestigious national art award. Will the Prime Minister commit to maintaining the amount of money given to support young artists?
questions.feedback: A good question for your constituency and for the party.

questions.text: What plans do the Government have for releasing secret files on alien visits to earth?
questions.feedback: The party and your constituents were a bit embarrassed. But the papers wanted to know why you were asking about aliens.

questions.text: Statistics in my constituency show that having more police patrolling the local area reduces crime. Will the Prime Minister commit to increasing policing budgets across the UK?
questions.feedback: Your constituents would be happy to get more police, but the Prime Minister didn't like to be surprised with a request for increasing budgets!

missed.feedback: PMQs is a great chance to check the work of the Government (and raise your profile).

question.title: Crime and Justice Minister
question.notes: A notorious thief has stolen the Queen's Crown Jewels after getting early release from an eight year sentence for robbery. 'The Magician' (aka Kenny Stidwill) amazed the world with his spectacular raid of the Tower of London's vaults.

questions.text: What meetings has the Minister had with police about the Tower of London robbery and what steps are being taken to recover the Crown Jewels?
questions.feedback: It's a high profile Question Time. Good question.

questions.text: Is this incident proof that the Government's approach to prison sentences has failed?
questions.feedback: A slightly aggressive question toward a Minister in your own party. The press noticed!

questions.text: How many thieves sentenced to prison terms served their full sentences?
questions.feedback: The Minister's answer was taken as proof of both Government failure and success, depending on the newspaper.

missed.feedback: You missed out. Question Time is a good chance to check what the Government has been doing for your constituents and everyone else in the country.

question.title: Global Affairs Minister
question.notes: The Opposition party disagrees with the Government when it comes to giving money and aid to developing countries. The Shadow Minister for Global Affairs said: 'Of course we want to help developing countries, but aid often has negative effects. We should try to promote more trade instead.'

questions.text: I'd like to congratulate the Minister on the Government's foreign aid programme. Will the Government continue to maintain aid levels to help the world's poorest?
questions.feedback: Are you supporting the governing party now?

questions.text: Can the Minister explain why some money given to developing countries is not getting to the people that need it the most?
questions.feedback: The Shadow Minister appreciated your support!

questions.text: Will the Minister join me in celebrating World Turtle Day?
questions.feedback: The Minister wasn't interested in spending much time on your question.

questions.text: Will the Minister make a statement about the Government's aid programme in Africa?
questions.feedback: The Minister's answer listed plenty of Government success stories.

questions.text: It is all well and good giving money and resources to help developing countries, but what's in it for the UK?
questions.feedback: You might have a point, but most didn't like the tone of your question.

missed.feedback: You missed out. Question Time is a good chance to check what the Government has been doing for your constituents and everyone else in the country.

question.title: Crime and Justice Minister
question.notes: A notorious thief has stolen the Queen's Crown Jewels after getting early release from an 8 year sentence for robbery. 'The Magician' (aka Kenny Stidwill) amazed the world with his spectacular raid of the Tower of London's vaults.

questions.text: What meetings has the Minister had with police about the Tower of London robbery and what steps are being taken to recover the Crown Jewels?
questions.feedback: It's a high profile Question Time. Good question.

questions.text: Is this incident proof that the Government's approach to prison sentences has failed?
questions.feedback: Your question highlighted a potential area where the Government needs to improve.

questions.text: How many thieves sentenced to prison terms served their full sentences?
questions.feedback: The Minister's answer was taken as proof of both Government failure and success, depending on the newspaper.

missed.feedback: You missed out. Question Time is a good chance to check what the Government has been doing for your constituents and everyone else in the country.

question.title: Prime Minister
question.notes: MPs fill the House of Commons Chamber to be part of Prime Minister's Questions. This is when MPs have the chance to ask the Prime Minister about anything the Government is doing.

questions.text: Can the Prime Minister make a statement about the effectiveness of foreign aid to the developing world?
questions.feedback: Not a great question for highlighting where the Government's going wrong. The Prime Minister was able to talk about the Government's successes.

questions.text: A high profile robbery has been carried out by a thief released early from jail. Will the Prime Minister admit the Government's approach to prison sentencing has failed?
questions.feedback: Your party was happy with that question. You highlighted an area where the Government might need to improve.

questions.text: Does the Prime Minister know what the capital of Indonesia is?
questions.feedback: It's Jakarta. Your questioning style was treated harshly by the papers: 'Clueless MP embarrasses party'.

questions.text: My constituent recently won a prestigious national art award. Will the Prime Minister commit to maintaining the amount of money given to support young artists?
questions.feedback: A good question for your constituency.

questions.text: What plans does the Government have for releasing secret files on alien visits to earth?
questions.feedback: The party and your constituents were a bit embarrassed. But the papers wanted to know why you were asking about aliens.

questions.text: Statistics in my constituency show that having more police patrolling the local area reduces crime. Will the Prime Minister commit to increasing policing budgets across the UK?
questions.feedback: Your constituents would be happy to get more police. And the Prime Minister was put on the spot with your request for increasing budgets! Your party was impressed.

missed.feedback: PMQs is a great chance to check the work of the Government (and raise your profile).
